questions.question_text_1: In a message queue system, if the consumer is slower than the producer, what is likely to occur first?
question_texts: In a message queue system, if the consumer is slower than the producer, what is likely to occur first?

options.option_text: Messages will accumulate in the queue
The consumer will speed up automatically
The producer will block until the consumer is ready

questions.question_text_1: What does "reactivity" mean in the context of frontend frameworks like Vue.js?
question_texts: What does "reactivity" mean in the context of frontend frameworks like Vue.js?

options.option_text: The component will reload when data changes
It disables direct access to state
The DOM updates automatically when the underlying reactive data changes

options.option_text: It stores output in session storage
It skips route execution for repeated inputs

To control which domains can access resources

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are the potential benefits of using a message broker?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are the potential benefits of using a message broker?

options.option_text: A message broker makes the network scalable for adding more servers to thenetwork.
A message broker allows two servers in a network to directly communicatewith each other, without an intermediary.
A message broker is not suited in case of traffic spikes, as messages areretained in the queue until processed.
A message broker can be used for batch processing of messages.

questions.question_text_1: Which statements about webhooks are correct?
question_texts: Which statements about webhooks are correct?

options.option_text: They use HTTP POST requests typically
They require polling from the client

questions.question_text_1:
A popular e-commerce platform needs to notify multiple third-party services (inventory management, email marketing, analytics) whenever a customer places an order. The development team is considering different approaches to handle these notifications. 
Scenario: When an order is placed, the system needs to: 
● Update inventory levels in an external warehouse system ● Send a welcome email through a third-party email service ● Log analytics data to an external tracking service ● Update customer loyalty points in a CRM system 
Which of the following statements about using webhooks for this scenario is MOST accurate?
question_texts:
A popular e-commerce platform needs to notify multiple third-party services (inventory management, email marketing, analytics) whenever a customer places an order. The development team is considering different approaches to handle these notifications. 
Scenario: When an order is placed, the system needs to: 
● Update inventory levels in an external warehouse system ● Send a welcome email through a third-party email service ● Log analytics data to an external tracking service ● Update customer loyalty points in a CRM system 
Which of the following statements about using webhooks for this scenario is MOST accurate?

options.option_text: Webhooks are not suitable for this use case because they require the e-commerce platform to continuously poll each third-party service to check if they're ready to receive data, which would create unnecessary network overhead.

Webhooks should be avoided in this scenario because they operatesynchronously, meaning the customer's order placement would be delayed until all third-party services have successfully processed their notifications.

Webhooks provide an ideal solution as they allow the e-commerce platform topush real-time notifications to all subscribed third-party services immediately when an order is placed, eliminating the need for these services to repeatedly poll for updates.
Webhooks are primarily designed for read-only operations and cannot handlecomplex data payloads like order information, making them unsuitable for e-commerce transaction notifications.

questions.question_text_1: What is the main advantage of using caching in a Flask-based web application?
question_texts: What is the main advantage of using caching in a Flask-based web application?

options.option_text: It eliminates the need for client-side rendering
It reduces server load by reusing responses for repeated requests
It encrypts data transmission between server and client
It avoids the need for database interactions completely

options.option_text: Using time.sleep() blocks the event loop and is recommended for async tasks
Celery allows long-running tasks to be executed asynchronously
Polling is a strategy to check task status periodically
Flask + Celery + Redis is a common stack for async task management

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are true about mutations and actions in Vuex?
question_texts: Which of the following are true about mutations and actions in Vuex?

options.option_text: Only actions can call APIs through fetch call
The class "active" will only be applied to the div element if the variable"isActive" evaluates to true.
The class "disabled" will be applied to the div element when the variable"isEnabled" evaluates to false.
The class "text-bold" will always be applied to the div element regardless ofthe "hasBoldText" variable value.
All three classes ("active", "text-bold", "disabled") will always be applied to thediv element.
If "isEnabled" is undefined, the "disabled" class will not be applied to the divelement.
The class "text-bold" will only be applied if the variable "hasBoldText" existsand evaluates to a truthy value.

questions.question_text_1:
Prashant and Nikita are creating a quiz question paper collaboratively. They are each working on different sections — and complete their tasks in parallel. Meanwhile, Mayur is enjoying a single-player game that finishes when the game loop ends. 
To compare productivity: 
● If Prashant and Nikita (together) finish faster than Mayur, the winner is "Team". ● If Mayur finishes faster, he wins. ● If both take the same time, Mayur wins by default. 
You are simulating this scenario in the browser.Prashant and Nikita are represented using parallel Promises. Mayur is represented using a single Promise. The frontend must calculate who finishes first using asynchronous logic, and display the result.

  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Diploma Level: Modern Application Development II"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
### **A. Asynchronous JavaScript & Promises**
- **Key Concepts**:
  - `async/await`, `Promise`, `Promise.all`, `Promise.race`, `.then()`, `.catch()`, `.finally()`.
  - Event loop, microtask queue, and macrotask queue.
  - **Closures** and **lexical scoping** in asynchronous contexts.
- **Critical Code Snippets**:
  ```javascript
  // Promise chaining
  new Promise((resolve, reject) => { /* ... */ })
    .then(data => { /* ... */ })
    .catch(error => { /* ... */ })
    .finally(() => { /* ... */ });

  // Promise.all (parallel execution)
  Promise.all([promise1, promise2]).then(results => { /* ... */ });

  // Promise.race (first to resolve/reject)
  Promise.race([promise1, promise2]).then(winner => { /* ... */ });
  ```
- **Execution Order**:
  - Synchronous code runs first.
  - `await` pauses execution until the `Promise` resolves.
  - `.then()` and `.catch()` are microtasks (higher priority than `setTimeout`).

---

### **B. Vue.js Fundamentals**
#### **1. Reactivity System**
- **Core Idea**: The DOM updates **automatically** when reactive data changes.
- **Reactive Data**:
  - Declared in `data()`, `computed`, or using `Vue.reactive()` (Vue 3).
  - **Not reactive**: Properties added after initialization (use `Vue.set` or `this.$set` in Vue 2).
- **Computed Properties**:
  - Cached and reactive.
  - Example:
    ```javascript
    computed: {
      filteredTasks() {
        return this.tasks.filter(task => task.status !== 'complete');
      }
    }
    ```

#### **2. Components & Props**
- **Parent-Child Communication**:
  - **Props** (parent → child, read-only).
  - **Events** (`$emit`, child → parent).
- **Slots**:
  - **Default slots**: `<slot></slot>`
  - **Named slots**: `<slot name="header"></slot>`
  - **Scoped slots**: Pass data from child to parent.
    ```html
    <template v-slot:header="slotProps">
      {{ slotProps.user.name }}
    </template>
    ```

#### **3. Vuex (State Management)**
- **State**: Single source of truth.
- **Getters**: Computed properties for state.
- **Mutations**: **Synchronous** state updates.
- **Actions**: **Asynchronous** operations (can commit mutations).
  ```javascript
  actions: {
    fetchData({ commit }) {
      return api.call().then(response => {
        commit('SET_DATA', response);
      });
    }
  }
  ```

#### **4. Vue Router**
- **Dynamic Routes**:
  ```javascript
  { path: '/user/:id', component: UserProfile }
  ```
- **Navigation Methods**:
  - `this.$router.push()` (adds to history).
  - `this.$router.replace()` (replaces current route).
  - `this.$router.go(-1)` (goes back).
- **Named Routes**:
  ```javascript
  this.$router.push({ name: 'UserProfile', params: { id: 123 } });
  ```

---

### **C. Flask & Backend Development**
#### **1. Caching**
- **`@cache.cached()`** (Flask-Caching):
  - Skips route execution for repeated inputs (reduces server load).
- **Cache Backends**: Redis, Memcached, filesystem.

#### **2. Asynchronous Tasks (Celery)**
- **Use Case**: Offload long-running tasks (e.g., sending emails).
- **Setup**:
  ```python
  from celery import Celery
  app = Celery('tasks', broker='redis://localhost:6379/0')
  ```
- **Task Definition**:
  ```python
  @app.task
  def send_email(to, body):
      # Async email logic
      return True
  ```
- **Flask + Celery + Redis**: Common stack for async task management.

#### **3. CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**
- **Purpose**: Control which domains can access resources.
- **Flask-CORS Setup**:
  ```python
  from flask_cors import CORS
  CORS(app, resources={r"/api/*": {"origins": "http://example.com"}})
  ```
- **Preflight Requests**: `OPTIONS` request before actual request.

---

### **D. Web Performance Optimization**
#### **1. Lighthouse Metrics**
- **First Contentful Paint (FCP)**: Time until first DOM content is rendered.
- **Time to Interactive (TTI)**: Time until page is fully interactive.
- **Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS)**: Measures visual stability.

#### **2. Performance Factors**
- **Number of HTTP requests** (reduce via bundling, sprites).
- **File size of resources** (compress images, minify JS/CSS).
- **Caching strategies** (ETags, Cache-Control headers).

---

### **E. Message Queues & Brokers**
#### **1. Message Queue Behavior**
- **Producer-Consumer Model**:
  - If **consumer is slower**, messages **accumulate in the queue**.
  - If **producer is slower**, the queue remains empty.
- **Use Cases**:
  - Decoupling services.
  - Handling traffic spikes (messages retained until processed).

#### **2. Webhooks**
- **Definition**: HTTP callbacks (server-to-server communication).
- **How It Works**:
  1. Event occurs (e.g., order placed).
  2. Source server sends `POST` request to a predefined URL (webhook endpoint).
  3. No polling required (real-time).
- **Example**:
  ```javascript
  // E-commerce order webhook
  fetch("https://third-party-service/webhook", {
    method: "POST",
    body: JSON.stringify({ orderId: 123, status: "placed" })
  });
  ```

---

### **F. Security Best Practices**
#### **1. Supply Chain Attacks**
- **Mitigation Strategies**:
  - **Version pinning**: Lock dependencies to specific versions.
  - **Reduce dependencies**: Fewer packages = smaller attack surface.
  - **Audit tools**: `npm audit`, `yarn audit`.

#### **2. Secure Storage**
- **`localStorage` vs `sessionStorage`**:
  - `localStorage`: Persists across sessions.
  - `sessionStorage`: Cleared when tab closes.
- **Limitations**:
  - Both are **synchronous** and **string-only**.
  - **Not secure** for sensitive data (use `HttpOnly` cookies or backend storage).

---

### **G. JavaScript Deep Dives**
#### **1. `this` Binding**
- **Arrow Functions**: Lexical `this` (inherits from parent scope).
- **Regular Functions**: `this` depends on how it’s called.
  ```javascript
  const obj = {
    value: 10,
    regular: function() { return this.value; }, // 10
    arrow: () => this.value // undefined (or global/window in non-strict mode)
  };
  ```

#### **2. Destructuring & Spread Operator**
- **Object Destructuring**:
  ```javascript
  const { name, ...rest } = user; // rest = { age: 25, city: 'Boston' }
  ```
- **Spread Operator**:
  ```javascript
  const newUser = { ...user, location: user.city }; // Shallow copy
  ```

---

## **2. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Asynchronous JavaScript**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Synchronous Code] --> B[Macrotask Queue: setTimeout, I/O]
    A --> C[Microtask Queue: Promises, MutationObserver]
    C --> D[Event Loop]
    D -->|Prioritizes Microtasks| E[Execute .then/.catch]
    D -->|Then Macrotasks| B
    E --> F[Promise.race]
    E --> G[Promise.all]
    F --> H[First Settled]
    G --> I[All Settled]
```

### **Graph 2: Vue.js Reactivity & Components**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Vue Instance] --> B[Reactive Data]
    A --> C[Template]
    B -->|Change| D[Trigger Reactivity]
    D --> E[Update Virtual DOM]
    E --> F[Patch Real DOM]
    A --> G[Components]
    G --> H[Props Down]
    G --> I[Events Up]
    G --> J[Slots: Default/Named/Scoped]
```

### **Graph 3: Flask & Backend Ecosystem**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Flask App] --> B[Routes]
    A --> C[Flask-CORS]
    C --> D[Allow/Block Domains]
    B --> E[Synchronous Endpoints]
    B --> F[Asynchronous Tasks]
    F --> G[Celery]
    G --> H[Redis/RabbitMQ]
    A --> I[Caching]
    I --> J[@cache.cached]
    I --> K[Redis/Memcached]
```

### **Graph 4: Web Performance & Optimization**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Lighthouse Audit] --> B[FCP: First Contentful Paint]
    A --> C[TTI: Time to Interactive]
    A --> D[CLS: Cumulative Layout Shift]
    B --> E[Render-Blocking Resources]
    C --> F[JavaScript Execution]
    D --> G[Avoid Layout Shifts]
    E --> H[Minify CSS/JS]
    F --> I[Code Splitting]
    G --> J[Set Image Dimensions]
```

### **Graph 5: Message Queues & Webhooks**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Producer] -->|Send Message| B[Message Queue]
    B -->|Accumulate| C[Consumer]
    C -->|Slow| D[Queue Grows]
    C -->|Fast| E[Queue Empties]
    A --> F[Webhook Trigger]
    F -->|POST Request| G[Third-Party Service]
    G --> H[Real-Time Updates]
```

### **Graph 6: Security & Supply Chain**

## **3. Key Equations (Math/Logic)**
While this exam is primarily coding/conceptual, here are **logical flow equations** for async and reactivity:

1. **Promise Execution Time**:
   ```
   TotalTime(Promise.all) = Max(Promise1, Promise2, ..., PromiseN)
   TotalTime(Promise.race) = Min(Promise1, Promise2, ..., PromiseN)
   ```

2. **Vue Reactivity Trigger**:
   ```
   If (dataPropertyChanges) {
     RecomputeComputedProperties();
     UpdateVirtualDOM();
     PatchRealDOM();
   }
   ```

3. **Flask Caching Hit/Miss**:
   ```
   If (request in cache) {
     return cachedResponse;
   } else {
     executeRoute();
     cacheResponse();
   }
   ```
